questions.text: Marker for ectopic pregnancy is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

The correct answer is Beta hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin). Beta hCG is a hormone produced by the placenta during pregnancy. In the context of an ectopic pregnancy, which is a pregnancy located outside the uterine cavity (commonly in the fallopian tubes), the measurement of Beta hCG levels is crucial for diagnosis and management.

 

Beta hCG: In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, Beta hCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours. In ectopic pregnancies, these levels usually rise more slowly. Additionally, Beta hCG levels are used to determine the mode of management for unruptured ectopic pregnancies (medical, surgical, or expectant management) and to assess the discriminatory zone, which is the level of Beta hCG at which an intrauterine pregnancy should be visible on ultrasound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estradiol: This is a form of estrogen, a hormone involved in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy, but it is not a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option C. Progesterone: This hormone supports the early stages of pregnancy by preparing the uterine lining for implantation, but it is not specifically used to diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Estriol: Another form of estrogen produced during pregnancy, it is not used as a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG is the primary marker used to diagnose and manage ectopic pregnancies, providing essential information about pregnancy location and viability.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient's symptoms? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Ventricle

 

The patient’s presentation is characteristic of right ventricular failure, often secondary to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in chronic smokers.

 

Key clinical features include:

 

  • Shortness of breath: A common symptom in both left and right heart failure but is notably worsened by right heart failure due to fluid overload.
  • Bilateral pitting pedal edema: Indicates fluid retention, a hallmark of right ventricular failure.
  • Abdominal distension: Often due to ascites, which is related to increased venous pressure.
  • Elevated jugular venous pulse (JVP): Reflects increased central venous pressure due to right heart dysfunction.
  • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver): Due to congestion of blood in the liver secondary to increased venous pressure.

 

Right ventricular failure results from the right ventricle's inability to pump blood effectively to the lungs, leading to a backup of blood in the systemic venous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: Left ventricular failure primarily causes pulmonary congestion and edema due to the backflow of blood into the lungs. Symptoms like shortness of breath would predominate without the systemic venous congestion (e.g., pedal edema, elevated JVP, hepatomegaly) seen in right ventricular failure.

 

Option C. Aorta: An aortic abnormality would not directly cause the combination of symptoms described. Issues with the aorta generally result in systemic hypertension, aortic aneurysm, or dissection, which have different clinical presentations.

 

Option D. Mitral Valve: Mitral valve disease, particularly mitral stenosis or regurgitation, primarily affects the left atrium and ventricle, leading to pulmonary congestion and symptoms more indicative of left heart failure rather than the systemic congestion seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right ventricular failure is characterized by systemic venous congestion, which manifests as elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and abdominal distension. This condition is often seen in chronic smokers due to the impact of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on the heart.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea presents to the OPD. She has Tanner stage IV secondary sexual characters. Her karyotype is 46XX. FSH is 5 and LH is 13. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mullerian agenesis

 

The patient presents with primary amenorrhea, Tanner stage IV secondary sexual characteristics, a 46XX karyotype, and normal gonadotropin levels (FSH and LH). The development of secondary sexual characteristics indicates that the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis is functioning properly, which usually suggests normal ovarian function. Mullerian agenesis (also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) is a condition where the uterus and part of the vaginal canal are absent, but ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics remain normal. This condition commonly presents with primary amenorrhea in individuals with a 46XX karyotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadal dysgenesis: Gonadal dysgenesis refers to underdeveloped or non-functional gonads, leading to low estrogen levels and subsequent lack of secondary sexual characteristics. In this case, FSH and LH levels would typically be elevated, not normal.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: Kallmann syndrome is characterized by a lack of secondary sexual development due to low levels of gonadotropins (FSH and LH). This condition usually presents with delayed or absent puberty, unlike the normal Tanner stage IV development seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS): AIS involves individuals with a 46XY karyotype who are phenotypically female due to the body's inability to respond to androgens. This patient has a 46XX karyotype, ruling out AIS as a possible diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mullerian agenesis is a likely diagnosis in a patient with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual development, normal FSH/LH levels, and a 46XX karyotype.

questions.text: A male patient who was diagnosed with tuberculosis has successfully completed the full course of treatment. Subsequent to finishing both the intensive and continuation phases, the initial sputum examination was conducted. The results of this examination were negative. What is the current condition of the patient? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cured

 

A patient with negative sputum examination at the end of tuberculosis treatment indicates that the patient has been cured of the disease.

 

Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that primarily affects the lungs and causes pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • A TB case can be confirmed by positive results on smear microscopy and culture of biological specimens or diagnosed clinically by a clinician who prescribes a full course of TB treatment.
  • TB treatment consists of two phases: the intensive phase lasting for two months and the continuation phase lasting for four months.
  • Treatment involves four drugs in the intensive phase, namely isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, and isoniazid along with rifampicin and ethambutol in the continuation phase.
  • After completion of treatment, the patient's sputum/culture is tested and assigned one of the following outcomes: cured, treatment completed, treatment failed, lost to follow-up, died, or not evaluated, depending on the results of the test and the patient's medical history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Treatment Completed: Refers to a patient who has completed treatment without evidence of failure but lacks documented negative sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion.

 

Option C. Lost to Follow-Up: Refers to a patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for two consecutive months or more.

 

Option D. Treatment Failed: Refers to a patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after 5 months or more of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminologies:

 

  • Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion
  • Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable
  • Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more
  • Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
  • Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason
  • Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted

choices.text: Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery
Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the structure marked with the arrow in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

 

The corpus callosum is the largest fibre pathway in the brain. The corpus callosum is composed of the rostrum, genu, trunk or body, and splenium.

 

The corpus callosum is a large bundle of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain and allows for communication between them. It is supplied with blood by the anterior cerebral artery and the anterior communicating artery, which are both branches of the internal carotid artery.

 

The anterior cerebral artery supplies blood to the front and top of the brain, including the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres, which is where the corpus callosum is located. The anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and provides additional blood supply to the corpus callosum. Damage to the corpus callosum, such as from a stroke or traumatic brain injury, can disrupt communication between the two hemispheres and lead to a range of neurological symptoms depending on the location and severity of the damage.

 

The corpus callosum is the major commissural pathway connecting the cerebral hemispheres that receives its blood supply from anterior communicating artery, pericallosal artery, and posterior pericallosal artery”.

 

“Pericallosal artery is formed by branches of from anterior and posterior cerebral arteries (Mainly anterior cerebral artery). Pericallosal arteries which are derived from anterior cerebral arteries supply the anterior 4/5th of corpus callosum and posterior 1/5th is supplied by pericallosal artery derived from posterior cerebral artery.”

 

Since the arrow is near the posterior end of body answer is ACommA + ACA
If the arrow was near the anterior end, answer will be ACommA + ACA
If the arrow is on splenium, the answer will be ACA + PCA
 

 

 

   

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery: The anterior cerebral artery does supply the corpus callosum, but the middle cerebral artery does not play a significant role in its blood supply.

 

Option B. Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery: While the anterior cerebral artery supplies the corpus callosum, the posterior cerebral artery primarily supplies the posterior parts of the brain, including the occipital lobes. It doesn't contribute significantly to the blood supply of the corpus callosum.

 

Option D. Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery: Neither the middle cerebral artery nor the posterior cerebral artery is the primary supplier of blood to the corpus callosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corpus callosum's blood supply is primarily provided by the anterior cerebral artery, with additional support from the anterior communicating artery. This knowledge is crucial in understanding potential impacts of circulatory issues within the brain, such as strokes, which could affect interhemispheric communication.

questions.text: Function of IL-8 is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Chemotaxis

 

Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a cytokine that primarily functions as a chemokine. It plays a crucial role in the immune response by attracting and activating neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation through chemotaxis. This movement of neutrophils to the affected area helps in fighting infections effectively, as they are key cells in the innate immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fever: Fever is primarily induced by cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-alpha, not IL-8. These cytokines act on the hypothalamus to increase body temperature, which is a part of the systemic inflammatory response.

 

Option C. Lymphocyte proliferation: Lymphocyte proliferation is mainly associated with cytokines such as IL-2, which stimulates the growth of T cells. IL-8 does not play a direct role in lymphocyte proliferation.

 

Option D. TH1 activation: TH1 activation is driven by cytokines like IL-12 and IFN-gamma, which promote the differentiation of T-helper cells into the TH1 subtype. IL-8 is not involved in this process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary function of IL-8 is to induce chemotaxis, particularly attracting neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation.

questions.text: A patient with history of alcoholism presented with right hypochondriac pain and fever. He had an episode of diarrhoea 1 week prior. USG abdomen reveals a liver abscess of around 25 cc in right lobe. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medical management

 

  • This patient with USG revealing abscess in the liver most likely has an amebic liver abscess. Since next best is asked, medical management should be started first.

 

Amoebic liver abscess:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PAIR: PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration) is more commonly used for hydatid cysts and not the first-line treatment for amoebic liver abscesses.

 

Option B. Surgery: Surgical intervention is generally reserved for cases where there is no response to medical treatment or complications arise.

 

Option D. Percutaneous drainage: This can be considered if the abscess is large, at risk of rupture, or if there is no response to medical management. However, initial treatment should be medical management with antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For amoebic liver abscess, initial management should always begin with medical therapy using metronidazole, chloroquine, and diloxanide furoate.
  •  Drainage or aspiration is considered based on the size and risk of rupture of the abscess.

questions.text: A person working in a restaurant comes to the casualty with a huge burn on his abdomen. On examination, the injury looks like below. What is the most likely cause of the injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Moist heat

 

  • In the case scenario given above the patient has suffered from a ‘Scald injury’

  • Clinical presentation - erythema, blisters, and a line of demarcation

  • Cause of scald - application of liquid above 60°C or from steam which is moist heat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electric burn: Electric burns typically have entry and exit points and are caused by electrical currents passing through the body, which is not seen in the image.

 

Option B. Chemical burn: Chemical burns result from exposure to corrosive substances and may have different patterns and additional signs such as discoloration or tissue damage beyond just blisters and erythema.

 

Option C. Dry heat: Burns caused by dry heat, such as flames or hot objects, usually present with charring or a different burn pattern compared to scald injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of the burn injury shown in the image is moist heat, specifically a scald injury caused by hot liquids or steam.

 

TYPES of SCALD INJURIES

 

  • Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.

  • Accidental Splash burns

  • Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pressure in her chest. Her doctor orders an ultrasound, which reveals a retrosternal goiter. The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neck

 

Explanation:

 

The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck. This is because the thyroid gland is anatomically located in the neck, and even when a goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access for surgical removal. The retrosternal portion of the goiter can usually be mobilized and delivered into the neck for excision without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches. The vascular supply of the goiter also predominantly comes from cervical vessels like the inferior thyroid artery, making the neck approach feasible and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chest: Surgical approaches through the chest are typically not used for retrosternal goiters. Accessing the thyroid gland through the chest would involve more invasive procedures, such as thoracotomy, and is generally reserved for rare cases with specific indications, such as very large goiters extending deeply into the chest cavity.

 

Option C. Median Sternotomy: Median sternotomy involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to access structures within the chest, particularly the heart and major blood vessels. While median sternotomy is common for cardiac surgeries, it is not the primary approach for treating retrosternal goiters, which can typically be addressed via the neck.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the neck is the commonest and preferred approach for the surgical removal of retrosternal goiters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common and preferred surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter is via the neck due to its direct access to the thyroid gland and the feasibility of mobilizing the goiter from this region.

questions.text: Epithelial lining of trachea is made of which type of cells? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells

 

The epithelial lining of the trachea consists of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium appears to be layered (stratified) due to the varying positions of the nuclei within the cells, but in reality, all cells are attached to the basement membrane, making it a "pseudostratified" layer. The presence of cilia on the apical surface of the cells helps in the movement of mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract, which is crucial for maintaining respiratory health.

 

 

 

Note - Kartagener Syndrome which is characterized by a triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and infertility. This syndrome is linked to defects in the ciliary structure and function, known as primary ciliary dyskinesia, affecting not just respiratory epithelium but also other ciliated cells in the body, such as those in the reproductive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciliated columnar cells: Although the cells are ciliated, they are not simply columnar; they are pseudostratified columnar cells.

 

Option B. Non-ciliated cuboidal cells: This type of epithelium is typically found in smaller ducts and glands, not in the respiratory tract, making it incorrect for the trachea.

 

Option D. Simple columnar cells: This type of epithelium is found in areas like the gastrointestinal tract, where absorption is a key function. It is not characteristic of the trachea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trachea is lined with pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, which plays a critical role in trapping and moving particles out of the respiratory system to keep the airways clear.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions Hamman’s sign can be appreciated?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pneumomediastinum

 

Hamman’s sign can be elicited in Pneumomediastinum.

 

Hamman's sign refers to the presence of a crunching or crackling sound that coincides with each heartbeat.

 

Pneumomediastinum occurs due to entry of gas/air into mediastinum.

 

Causes: Boerhaave Syndrome, Trauma to chest, Esophageal rupture, complication of medical procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hamman's sign, a crunching or crackling sound with each heartbeat, is associated with pneumomediastinum caused by the entry of air into the mediastinum.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with anemia. What is the most common cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia across all age groups, including older adults. It occurs when the body's iron stores are depleted, leading to reduced production of hemoglobin and red blood cells. This condition is especially common in older adults due to factors such as poor dietary intake, gastrointestinal bleeding, and malabsorption.

 

In elderly patients, it is crucial to rule out underlying causes of iron deficiency anemia, particularly gastrointestinal malignancies such as colorectal cancer. For postmenopausal women and elderly men presenting with anemia, investigations such as colonoscopy or fecal occult blood tests are important to identify or exclude potential sources of chronic blood loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: This type of anemia is common in patients with chronic infections, inflammatory diseases, or malignancies, but it is not the most common cause of anemia in the general elderly population.

 

Option C. Aplastic anemia:  A rare condition characterized by pancytopenia and bone marrow failure. It is not a common cause of anemia in the elderly.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic syndrome:  A group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells, more common in older adults, but not as prevalent as iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia, especially in elderly patients, and requires thorough evaluation to rule out serious underlying conditions such as gastrointestinal malignancies.

choices.text: Need for blood transfusion
Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS
Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS
Risk of peripartum hysterectomy

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), the main risks include bleeding requiring transfusion, bladder injury, and possibly peripartum hysterectomy. Bowel injury is less commonly associated with PAS unless extreme or exceptional surgical complications occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Need for blood transfusion: It is common to counsel about the need for blood transfusion due to the high risk of hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS: Bladder injury is a significant risk if the placenta invades the bladder area.

 

Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy: Peripartum hysterectomy may be necessary if the placenta is inseparable from the uterus.

 

Educational objective:

 

When counseling a patient with a history of previous cesarean sections and PAS, focus on the more likely complications such as significant bleeding, bladder injury, and the possibility of needing a hysterectomy, rather than bowel injury.

questions.text: INSURE technique is used in newborn, born with which condition?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline membrane disease

 

The INSURE technique stands for INtubate, SURfactant, and Extubate. This method is used primarily in the management of preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease. The procedure involves:

 

  1. Intubating the newborn to establish a secure airway.
  2. Administering surfactant directly into the lungs to reduce surface tension and improve lung function.
  3. Extubating the newborn after the surfactant has been given to allow for spontaneous breathing with the aid of non-invasive ventilation, if necessary.

 

Hyaline membrane disease occurs in preterm infants due to the immaturity of the lungs and a deficiency of surfactant, a substance that prevents the alveoli in the lungs from collapsing. The INSURE technique is effective in providing the necessary surfactant and reducing the severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meconium aspiration syndrome: This option is incorrect because meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in post-term infants who inhale meconium-stained amniotic fluid, leading to respiratory distress. The INSURE technique is not used for this condition.

 

Option B. Transiente tachypnea of newborn: This option is incorrect because transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a self-limited condition seen in term infants caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. It typically resolves without the need for surfactant administration.

 

Option D. Neonatal jaundice: This option is incorrect because neonatal jaundice, caused by elevated bilirubin levels, is not related to lung function or surfactant deficiency. The INSURE technique is not applicable to this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The INSURE technique (Intubate, Surfactant, Extubate) is primarily used in preterm infants with hyaline membrane disease to administer surfactant and improve lung function.

questions.text: Chronic alcoholic patient presented with confusion, Wernicke's aphasia and unstable gate. Patient has deficiency of:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vit B1

 

The presentation of confusion, Wernicke's aphasia (a type of language impairment), and an unstable gait (ataxia) is highly indicative of Wernicke's encephalopathy, a condition commonly associated with chronic alcoholism and thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency. Alcoholism can lead to poor dietary intake and impaired absorption of thiamine, making this deficiency particularly common in this population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, poor wound healing, and fatigue. While severe scurvy can affect mental status, it does not typically present with Wernicke's aphasia or ataxia.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is primarily associated with bone disorders like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. It can also contribute to muscle weakness and pain, but it does not typically cause confusion, language impairment, or ataxia as seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Vitamin B3 deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While dementia could overlap with confusion, pellagra does not typically present with Wernicke's aphasia or ataxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms described, including confusion, Wernicke's aphasia, and an unstable gait, are indicative of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is often associated with thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Chronic alcoholism can lead to poor nutritional intake and impaired absorption of essential nutrients, including thiamine. Thiamine is essential for the metabolism of glucose, and its deficiency can result in neurological symptoms.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 542

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the ENT OPD with a complaint of nasal obstruction for the past two months. Her mother also reports foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On nasal endoscopy, the obstruction caused by crust formation is noted. She denies any bad smell. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atrophic Rhinitis

 

Explanation:

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge. The patient’s denial of the bad smell indicates anosmia, which is common in atrophic rhinitis. This condition typically leads to the formation of crusts within the nasal cavity, causing obstruction and a foul odor noticed by others but not by the patient due to their reduced sense of smell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinitis Medicamentosa: This condition results from prolonged use of nasal decongestant drops (e.g., oxymetazoline or xylometazoline), leading to rebound nasal congestion, not crust formation or foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option B. Rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, it presents with polypoid masses in the nasal cavity but not with crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.

 

 

Option D. Rhinoscleroma: Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, it presents with a hard, woody nose and specific histopathological findings, not just crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis presents with chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge, often accompanied by anosmia.

choices.text: Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith
Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.text: An elderly lady presents with abdominal pain and distension. She has a history of chronic constipation. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sigmoid volvulus

 

Explanation:

 

The abdominal X-ray shows a characteristic "coffee bean sign," which is indicative of a sigmoid volvulus. This radiological sign represents a massively distended sigmoid colon twisted on itself, resembling a bent tube or coffee bean. This condition is more common in elderly individuals, particularly those with a history of chronic constipation, due to the increased bowel length and mobility, combined with decreased bowel tone. Sigmoid volvulus can lead to severe abdominal pain and distension, as observed in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith: Typically presents with signs of obstruction but lacks the specific 'coffee bean' appearance associated with volvulus.

 

Option C. Cecal volvulus: Would show a single dilated loop of bowel, often with haustrations, and generally appears in a different location and shape compared to the sigmoid volvulus.

 

Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation: Would likely show signs of free air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, which is not visible in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

 

Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve. Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms  described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS): This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. While MPS can affect the eyes, leading to problems like corneal clouding and glaucoma, the key symptoms often include developmental delay, skeletal and joint abnormalities, and coarse facial features. Eye-related symptoms are typically not the first presenting symptoms in MPS.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This refers to a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth. Congenital cataracts can cause a variety of symptoms including a noticeable white, grey, or yellow spot in the pupil, nystagmus (uncontrolled eye movements), and yes, potentially photophobia. However, lacrimation (excessive tearing) is not a typical symptom of cataracts.

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: This condition is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborns. Typically, it's caused by bacteria acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother. The primary symptoms include redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, and discharge, which may be watery or pus-like. Photophobia can be a symptom, but it's not as common as in some other conditions like congenital glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text:
Vaccination against which of the following is recommended in the elderly? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Varicella zoster virus
  2. Rotavirus
  3. Measles
  4. Pneumococcal meningitis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

The vaccination recommendations for the elderly typically include vaccines for Varicella Zoster Virus (to prevent shingles) and Pneumococcal meningitis (to prevent pneumococcal diseases, including meningitis).

 

  • Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV): The recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) is recommended for adults 50 years and older to prevent shingles and its complications.
  • Pneumococcal meningitis: The pneumococcal vaccines (PCV13 and PPSV23) are recommended for adults 65 years and older to protect against pneumococcal diseases, including meningitis and pneumonia.

 

Educational objective

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is seen in methanol intoxication? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

 

Methanol intoxication leads to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap & high osmolal gap. Methanol is metabolized in the body to formic acid, which is a strong acid. The accumulation of formic acid in the bloodstream results in an increase in hydrogen ion concentration, leading to acidosis. The high anion gap indicates that there are unmeasured anions (such as formate) contributing to the acidosis. In addition to causing a high anion gap, methanol intoxication also leads to a high osmolal gap, which is another diagnostic clue in cases of toxic alcohol ingestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication does not cause alkalosis. Instead, it causes acidosis due to the production of formic acid.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because the acidosis caused by methanol intoxication is characterized by a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formate, a byproduct of methanol metabolism.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication leads to acidosis, not alkalosis, and the anion gap is elevated, not normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol intoxication causes metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formic acid.

questions.text: Defect in which of the following essential amino acids metabolism can cause cardiac problems:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methionine

 

Explanation

 

Option B. Methionine: Correct Answer. Methionine metabolism defects can lead to homocystinuria, a condition characterized by elevated levels of homocysteine in the blood. High levels of homocysteine are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, such as thrombosis, atherosclerosis, and other vascular problems. The cardiac issues in homocystinuria are related to the damaging effects of high homocysteine levels on blood vessels.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid involved in the synthesis of serotonin and niacin (Vitamin B3). Defects in tryptophan metabolism are more likely to affect neurological and mental health, rather than directly causing cardiac problems.

 

Option C. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is a branched-chain amino acid, and while disorders in its metabolism (like Maple Syrup Urine Disease) can have serious health consequences, they are not typically known to directly cause cardiac problems. These conditions more commonly affect the nervous system and metabolic balance.

 

Option D. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine metabolism defects lead to phenylketonuria (PKU). While untreated PKU can lead to severe neurological problems due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, it does not primarily cause cardiac problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Defect in the metabolism of methionine can cause homocystinuria which is associated with high risk of cardiovascular disease.
  • Classical homocystinuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme, cystathionine beta Synthase.
  • Clinical features: failure to thrive, developmental delay, ectopia lentis, severe myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, and optic atrophy. Progressive mental retardation, skeletal abnormalities may resemble Marfan syndrome. Thromboembolic episodes may be seen at any age. Elevated homocysteine level is a risk factor for CAD, CVA, PAD and DVT.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4326479/

questions.text: A patient has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Identify the structure as marked? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic artery

 

The image provided shows an intraoperative view during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, focusing on the Calot's triangle. This area is critical for identifying key anatomical structures to safely remove the gallbladder.

 

Calot's triangle is bordered by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior border of the liver. The "critical view of safety" is a surgical technique used to clearly identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct before clipping and cutting them.

 

In the image, the marked structure is the inner one, closer to the liver. This inner structure is the cystic artery. The outer structure, which is away from the liver and entering the gallbladder, is the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic duct: The cystic duct is the tube that connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. In the image, it is the outer structure marked CD, which is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option C. Right hepatic artery: This artery supplies blood to the right lobe of the liver and is not typically involved in the structures identified within Calot's triangle during a cholecystectomy.

 

Option D. Hepatic duct: The hepatic duct is part of the biliary duct system, joining with the cystic duct to form the common bile duct. It is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is crucial to identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct within Calot's triangle to prevent injury to the biliary structures and ensure a safe surgical procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscle and adipose tissues

 

Explanation:

 

GLUT-4 glucose transporter is insulin dependent and is the only GLUT present in muscle and adipose tissues. So, muscles and adipose tissues are totally dependent on Insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. GLUT-2 allows the liver to take up glucose and store it as glycogen or use it for energy production, independent of insulin.

 

Option B. Pancreas: The pancreas also uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. In the pancreas, GLUT-2 plays a role in sensing blood glucose levels and regulating insulin secretion.

 

Option D. Placenta: The placenta uses GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. These transporters facilitate the basal uptake of glucose to support the energy needs of the placenta and fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Hip Circumference
HDL
Glucose
Hypertension

questions.text: Which is not considered in the diagnosis of Metabolic syndrome: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hip Circumference

 

Option A: Hip circumference is not typically considered as a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome. The criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome usually include a combination of factors such as central obesity (usually measured by waist circumference), elevated blood pressure, elevated fasting glucose, high triglycerides, and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein): HDL cholesterol is considered in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome. Low levels of HDL are one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option C. Glucose: Elevated fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option D. Hypertension: High blood pressure is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome. Hypertension is considered a component of metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. The diagnosis of metabolic syndrome involves the assessment of specific criteria related to various health parameters. The objective is to identify individuals at higher risk for these conditions so that preventive measures can be taken.

questions.text: A 3-year-old was brought to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing since 2 hours. A radiograph was done as shown below. What will be the next step to manage the patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Esophagoscopy

 

A round metallic foreign body lies in the midline just above the aortic knob, suggestive of a foreign body within the esophagus, the coin exceeds the diameter of the trachea. Also, both lung fields appear clear.  

 

A PA and lateral view X-ray of chest and abdomen should be done.

 

Treatment – Removal of foreign body by esophagoscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchoscopy: Used if there is suspicion that the foreign body might have entered the respiratory tract. In this scenario, the foreign body is in the esophagus, not the trachea.

 

Option B. Tracheostomy: Not appropriate in this case as there is no indication of airway compromise that cannot be managed by less invasive means.

 

Option D. Heimlich’s Maneuver: This is used for choking due to an airway obstruction, not for foreign bodies lodged in the esophagus. It's inappropriate and could potentially cause harm by forcing the object into a more problematic position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected esophageal foreign bodies in children, esophagoscopy is the preferred method for both confirmation and removal of the object. It ensures that the foreign body is safely and effectively retrieved while minimizing risk to the patient.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

 

The amount of radiation exposure follows Inverse Square law which states that the radiation Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Small blood vessels are radiosensitive.

 

Option C: Cancer cells are rapidly proliferating cells are most radiosensitive.

 

Option D: Bone marrow, gonads, bowel mucosa possess high radiosensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inverse Square Law is critical to understanding radiation dosage and safety in radiotherapy, ensuring that radiation exposure is managed correctly to maximize the therapeutic effect while minimizing harm to healthy tissues. This principle helps in planning and delivering radiation treatments effectively.

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Common intermittent source epidemic

 

Explanation:

 

The graph shows cases occurring at irregular intervals with gaps between them, indicating that people are exposed intermittently to the source of infection. This pattern is characteristic of a common intermittent source epidemic, where exposures occur sporadically, leading to multiple peaks over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Single exposure, point source epidemic: Characterized by a sudden rise and fall in the number of cases within a single incubation period, showing a single peak.

 

 

Options B. Multiple exposure, point source epidemic: Shows multiple peaks due to repeated exposures, but the rise and fall are not as sudden and are marked by secondary waves.

 

 

Options C. Propagated epidemic: Involves person-to-person transmission, typically showing a slow rise, a plateau, and a slow fall in the number of cases over time.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A common intermittent source epidemic is marked by cases appearing at irregular intervals, reflecting intermittent exposures to the source of infection.

choices.text: Is both intra and extra cellular
Can fuse with other organelles directly
Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome
Is a single membrane structure

questions.text: What can be the mechanism by which phagolysosome cause cell death in autophagy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome

 

Phagolysosome cause cell death by fusing with lysosome to form autophagolysosome.

 

Autophagy refers to lysosomal digestion of the cell’s own components. It is a survival mechanism in times of nutrient deprivation, so a cell can thrive by recycling its own contents.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Is both intra and extracellular: Autophagy is an intracellular process, not extracellular. It involves the internal digestion of cellular components and does not occur outside the cell.

 

Option B. Can fuse with other organelles directly: While autophagic vacuoles can engulf other organelles, the crucial step in autophagy involves the fusion with a lysosome to form the autophagolysosome, where degradation occurs.

 

Option D. Is a single membrane structure: The autophagic vacuole is initially a double-membrane structure that eventually fuses with a lysosome. The formation of the autophagolysosome is key to the degradation process in autophagy.

 

Educational Objective:


The fusion of an autophagic vacuole with a lysosome to form an autophagolysosome is a central step in the autophagy process, enabling the degradation and recycling of cellular components.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 72

questions.text: A pregnant lady with 34 weeks of amenorrhea has the following findings: LDH - 700 IU/L, platelets - 75,000/ mm3, serum bilirubin - 1.5 mg/dL, SGOT - 200 U/L, SGPT - 150 U/L, and BP - 140/96 mm Hg. Her coagulation profile and renal function tests are normal. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HELLP syndrome

 

HELLP Syndrome:

 

  • The given clinical scenario with elevated liver enzymes (SGOT and SGPT), elevated bilirubin, low platelet count, and hypertension is indicative of HELLP syndrome.
  • HELLP is an acronym for:
    • Hemolysis (H): Evidence of hemolysis can include elevated LDH.
    • Elevated Liver enzymes (EL): Both SGOT and SGPT are elevated.
    • Low Platelet count (LP): Platelet count is significantly reduced (below 100,000/mm³).
  • This syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia and requires immediate medical attention.
  • Management often involves the termination of pregnancy, with steroid cover for fetal lung maturity and magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for seizure prophylaxis and neuroprotection of the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy:

 

  • This condition typically occurs during the late second and third trimesters.
  • Diagnosis is based on the Swansea Criteria, requiring 6 or more specific findings, which often include renal impairment, liver impairment, hypoglycemia, and coagulation defects.
  • Liver biopsy would show microvascular steatosis.

 

 

Option C. Viral Hepatitis:

 

  • Viral hepatitis can occur at any gestational age and presents with jaundice.
  • It typically involves markedly elevated bilirubin and significantly raised SGOT and SGPT levels.
  • This scenario lacks the characteristic very high bilirubin levels seen in viral hepatitis.

 

Option D. Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy:

 

  • Usually occurs in the third trimester and presents with pruritus.
  • Lab findings typically show mildly elevated bilirubin, elevated SGOT and SGPT, and characteristically raised serum bile acids.
  • Renal impairment, high BP, and coagulation abnormalities are not seen in intrahepatic cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. It is a severe form of preeclampsia and necessitates urgent medical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no 1809, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their genetic abnormalities. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

 

HUNTINGTON CHOREA

 

 

EDWARD'S SYNDROME

 

 

 

PATAU SYNDROME

 

 

 

SICKLE CELL ANEMIA

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: High fetal head station

questions.text: All are causes of uterine dysfunction, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiparity

 

Explanation:

 

  • Multiparity is not a cause of uterine dysfunction; rather, nulliparity (the condition of a woman who has never given birth) is a recognized cause. Uterine dysfunction, particularly hypotonic uterine dysfunction, is associated with several factors, but multiparity is generally associated with a more efficient labor process due to the body's previous experience with childbirth.

 

Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction:

 

  • Neuraxial analgesia: The use of epidural or spinal anesthesia can interfere with uterine contractions.
  • Chorioamnionitis: This is an infection of the amniotic fluid and membranes, which can lead to inflammation and impaired uterine contractility.
  • Nulliparity: First-time mothers (nulliparous women) are more likely to experience uterine dysfunction due to the unconditioned nature of the uterine muscles.
  • Other factors:
    • Mechanical disruption of myometrial function by a fibroid or pelvic tumor
    • Maternal obesity
    • Uterine mullerian anomaly
    • Increased maternal age
    • Malposition and malpresentation of the fetus
    • Contracted pelvis

 

Other options:

 

Option A. High fetal head station: High fetal head station can be associated with labor dystocia and uterine dysfunction as it may indicate issues with the descent of the baby.

 

Option C. Multiparity: Neuraxial block (e.g., epidural) can interfere with effective uterine contractions, leading to uterine dysfunction.

 

Option D. Chorioamnionitis: Chorioamnionitis, an infection, can impair uterine contractions and lead to dysfunctional labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nulliparity, not multiparity, is a cause of uterine dysfunction. Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction include neuraxial analgesia, chorioamnionitis, nulliparity, and mechanical factors such as fibroids or pelvic tumors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg459, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 416

choices.text: Premature ovarian failure
Delayed blood transfusion reaction

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient came with a history of fatiguability and constipation for the past 1 year. She has a history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery 4 years ago. She has had lactational failure and never regained her periods after the delivery. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sheehan syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Sheehan syndrome:

 

  • The most probable diagnosis in a woman with lactational failure and postpartum amenorrhea, now presenting with fatiguability and constipation, is Sheehan syndrome.
  • Sheehan syndrome refers to panhypopituitarism occurring as a result of pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage.
  • The history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery indicates significant blood loss, which resulted in pituitary ischemia leading to this condition.
  • Symptoms such as fatiguability and constipation can be attributed to secondary hypothyroidism resulting from pituitary dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypothyroidism: While hypothyroidism can cause fatiguability and constipation, the history of postpartum amenorrhea and lactational failure makes Sheehan syndrome more likely. In Sheehan syndrome, hypothyroidism is a secondary consequence of pituitary dysfunction.

 

Option C. Premature ovarian failure: Premature ovarian failure typically presents with symptoms of estrogen deficiency such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness, along with amenorrhea. However, it does not account for the history of significant postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Delayed blood transfusion reaction: Delayed blood transfusion reactions usually present with symptoms such as jaundice, fever, and anemia, but they do not explain the chronic symptoms of fatiguability, constipation, lactational failure, and amenorrhea in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan syndrome is characterized by panhypopituitarism due to pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage, leading to symptoms such as lactational failure, amenorrhea, fatiguability, and constipation.

 

Ref: Page no 465, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: What is the most common route of the spread of retinoblastoma? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct invasion

 

Direct invasion is the most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma.

Direct invasion included the optic nerve and the other parts in contact with the tumour mass. Thus, Direct invasion is a better choice. 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignancy that arises from the neurosensory retina.
  • It is the most common primary intraocular cancer in children.
  • Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

 

There are four types of retinoblastomas:

 

  1. Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
  2. Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
  3. Mixed type
  4. Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated.

 

The child is usually brought to the surgeon on account of a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil, sometimes called leukocoria or amaurotic cat's eye.

 

 

Other modes of presentation include a convergent or divergent squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis.

 

If left untreated, retinoblastoma runs through the following stages:

 

  • The quiescent stage: lasting from 6 months to a year.
  • The glaucomatous stage: results in enlargement of the globe, with apparent or real proptosis. Pain is severe during this stage but is relieved when the tumor bursts through the sclera.
  • The stage of extraocular extension
  • The stage of metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve invasion: While possible, it is not the most common initial route of spread but is critical once involved, as it facilitates spread to the brain.

 

Option B. Hematogenous: Represents the method for distant metastasis rather than initial local spread.

 

Option D. Lymphatic spread: Uncommon in retinoblastoma since the eye lacks significant lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct invasion is the primary method of spread for retinoblastoma is essential in recognizing how the tumor progresses and impacts surrounding ocular structures. This knowledge is crucial for effective screening, early diagnosis, and management to prevent advanced stages of disease and potential metastasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cognitive dysfunction

 

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed based on specific criteria that include impairments in social interaction and communication, as well as restrictive and repetitive patterns of behavior. Abnormalities in social communication and socialization, as well as restricted interests and behaviors, are key components of the diagnostic criteria for ASD. However, cognitive dysfunction, while it may be present in some individuals with ASD, is not a primary criterion used to diagnose the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities in social communication: This statement is correct. Impaired social communication is a core feature of ASD and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option B. Abnormalities in socialisation: This statement is correct. Difficulties in socialization, which include challenges in social interaction, are also part of the diagnostic criteria for ASD.

 

Option C. Restriction in interests and behaviour: This statement is correct. Restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are essential criteria for diagnosing ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

choices.text: Na+ I- Symporter

questions.text: Identify the transporter of iodine from follicular cells to follicular cavity within the thyroid gland: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pendrin

 

The transport of iodine within the thyroid gland involves multiple steps, with specific transporters playing distinct roles. The sodium-iodide symporter (Na+ I- Symporter) is responsible for transporting iodine from the bloodstream into the thyroid follicular cells. However, once inside the follicular cells, iodine needs to be transported into the follicular cavity (colloid) where thyroid hormone synthesis occurs. This specific transport is carried out by the protein Pendrin, a chloride-iodide transporter. Pendrin moves iodine from the follicular cells into the colloid, facilitating the next steps of thyroid hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na+ I- Symporter: This symporter is involved in the initial uptake of iodine from the bloodstream into the follicular cells, not in the transport of iodine into the colloid.

 

Option C. Calmodulin: Calmodulin is a calcium-binding messenger protein, and it does not play a direct role in the transport of iodine within the thyroid gland.

 

Option D. Claudin: Claudin proteins are involved in the formation of tight junctions in cells and do not have a role in the transport of iodine for thyroid hormone synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pendrin is the transporter responsible for moving iodine from the follicular cells into the colloid of the thyroid gland, a crucial step in thyroid hormone production.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of shoulder of a 25-year-old male who suffered a shoulder injury and now exhibits swelling around the shoulder joint. Based on the X-ray, which structure(s) is/are probable sites of injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament

 

  • The provided image indicates an upward displacement of the clavicle, accompanied by a noticeable gap between the clavicle and the acromion.
  • This suggests potential injuries to both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

 

ACROMIOCLAVICULAR JOINT DISLOCATION

 

  • Acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury typically occurs due to a fall onto the acromion.
  • Stability of the AC joint is dependent upon both the AC and coracoclavicular (CC) ligaments.
  • An acromioclavicular joint separation occurs when the clavicle separates from the scapula.
  • It is commonly caused by a fall directly on the ‘point’ of the shoulder or by a direct blow received in a contact sport.
  • AC Joint separation is almost always the result of a sudden, traumatic event that can be attributed to a specific incident or action.
  • The two most common causes are either a direct blow to the shoulder (seen in football, rugby, or hockey), or a fall on to an outstretched hand (after falling off a bicycle).
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and swelling around the joint
    • Pain on movement of the arm
    • Depending on the grade, a bump may be present on the top of the shoulder where the clavicle ends
    • The joint may be very unstable
  • It is classified into type 1 to 6 by Rockwood classification according to the severity of the injury and position of the displaced bones.

 

 

 

 

  • Treatment according to the grades include:
    • Type I-III: Conservative management with velpeau bandage. The bandage pushes the lateral end of shoulder downwards and the arm upwards, thus maintaining the reduction.
    • Type IV-VI: Open reduction and internal fixation

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Coracoacromial ligament. Coracoacromial ligament originates from the medial border of the acromion and attaches to the lateral border of the coracoid process. This ligament forms a part of the coracoacromial arch and provides support to the humeral head. Coracoacromial ligament injury is mostly related to trauma or clavicular fracture and isolated injury to the coracoacromial ligament is rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acromioclavicular joint dislocation or separation, as shown in the image provided in the question, there is tear in the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

questions.text: Reiter's syndrome is associated with: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA B27

 

Explanation

 

Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 antigen. This association is part of a broader category of diseases called seronegative spondyloarthropathies. The key conditions linked with HLA-B27 include:

 

  • Ankylosing Spondylitis: This condition has the highest association with HLA-B27.
  • Psoriatic Arthritis: A form of arthritis that affects some people with psoriasis.
  • Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's Syndrome): Characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis.
  • Enteropathic Arthritis: Associated with inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. HLA B51: It is linked with Behçet's disease.

 

Option C. HLA DR4: Associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. HLA B8: Associated with diseases such as myasthenia gravis and celiac disease.

 

Educational Objectives:


Reiter's syndrome is part of the seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 antigen.

questions.text: What is the karyotype associated with this finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 47, XY (+21)


The image shows a single palmar crease, also known as a "simian crease," which is commonly associated with Down syndrome. Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra chromosome 21, resulting in the karyotype 47, XY (+21) in males or 47, XX (+21) in females. This condition leads to a variety of physical and intellectual disabilities, and the single palmar crease is one of the characteristic physical findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 45, XO: This karyotype represents Turner syndrome, a condition where a female has only one X chromosome. It is not associated with a single palmar crease.

 

Option C. 47, XY (+18): This karyotype is associated with Edward syndrome, or trisomy 18. Edward syndrome has a different set of physical characteristics, such as clenched fists with overlapping fingers and rocker-bottom feet, rather than a single palmar crease.

 

Option D. 47, XY (+13): This karyotype corresponds to Patau syndrome, or trisomy 13, which is associated with severe congenital anomalies including cleft lip/palate and polydactyly, not a single palmar crease.

 

Educational Objective:


Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is the most common non-preventable cause of intellectual disability and is associated with characteristic physical findings such as a single palmar crease.

questions.text: A female presented in dermatology OPD with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best step among the following options? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Evaluate for hyperandrogenism

 

  • Since the patient is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy, syndromes associated with acne should be evaluated and ruled out to reach a diagnosis. One of the important syndrome is HAIR-AN syndrome.
  • Hence, the next best step would be to evaluate for hyperandrogenism.

 

Important Syndromes Associated with Acne:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Looking for dietary triggers: It could be considered, but this should already be taken care of before prescribing isotretinoin and antibiotics.

 

Option C. Checking for antibiotic resistance: This seems an appropriate step but can’t prioritize over ruling out HAIR-AN syndrome in this patient.

 

Option D. Drug triggers are unlikely to be the primary cause of acne patient who is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. Moreover, lesions in Drug-induced acne are monomorphic and comedones are absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When faced with a female patient whose acne has not improved with oral isotretinoin and antibiotics, the next best step is to evaluate for hyperandrogenism, which can point to an underlying hormonal cause such as PCOS, necessitating a different treatment approach.

 

References: Williams Gynaecology 4th edition: page no 392-394

questions.text: In Pompe’s disease, enzyme deficiency is? (INICET May 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase

 

Pompe's disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type II or acid maltase deficiency, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency or absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase (also called acid alpha-glucosidase or acid maltase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen, a complex sugar molecule, into glucose within the lysosomes of cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is an enzyme involved in the regulation of glycolysis, the metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to produce energy in the form of ATP.

 

Option C. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase is an enzyme responsible for the breakdown of glycogen in muscle tissue. Its deficiency causes McArdle’s disease.

 

Option D. Lactate dehydrogenase: Lactate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in the conversion of lactate, a byproduct of anaerobic metabolism, back into pyruvate, which can enter the citric acid cycle for further energy production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with Pompe's disease, the deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase leads to the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly the muscles. This glycogen buildup affects the proper functioning of cells and tissues, causing a wide range of symptoms, primarily affecting the muscles and respiratory system.
